questions.text: All of the following open into the middle meatus except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The sphenoid sinus drains into the sphenoethmoidal recess.
  • Maxillary, frontal sinuses and anterior ethmoid sinuses drain into the middle meatus.
  • Posterior ethmoid air cells drain into the superior meatus.
  • The nasolacrimal duct opens into the inferior meatus.

questions.text: Office headache is seen in which sinusitis?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Frontal sinusitis shows characteristic periodicity, i.e. comes up on waking, gradually increases and reaches its peak by about midday and then starts subsiding. It is also called "office headache" because of its presence only during office hours.

Other symptoms of frontal sinusitis include:

  • Tenderness: On pressing the floor of the frontal sinus, just above the medial canthus
  • Nasal discharge
  • Oedemaof the upper eyelid

questions.text: A 40-year-old with chronic bacterial sinusitis presents with severe headache, fever, chills, exophthalmos, papilledema, and unilateral cranial nerve VI and III palsies. What is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • The patient's symptoms (severe headache, high fever, chills, exophthalmos, papilledema, and cranial nerve VI and III palsies) suggest cavernous sinus thrombosis, a life-threatening complication of chronic bacterial sinusitis.
  • An emergency contrast-enhanced CT scan (CECT) is critical to confirm the diagnosis, identify the extent of thrombosis, and rule out differential diagnoses like orbital cellulitis.
  • Immediate imaging guides urgent management, including antibiotics and possible surgical intervention.

Explanation of other options:

  • Nasal smear and culture sensitivity(Option A): These investigations do not assess complications like cavernous sinus thrombosis, which must be diagnosed radiologically.
  • Emergency endoscopic sinus surgery(option C): While source control may ultimately be necessary (e.g., for sphenoid sinus infection), immediate imaging must precede surgical intervention.
  • Emergency antral wash(option D): Irrigation of the maxillary sinus is insufficient and not appropriate for suspected intracranial complications.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old patient presents with facial pain and nasal congestion for one week. On examination, there is tenderness over the cheeks, purulent nasal discharge in the middle meatus, and worsening pain when bending forward. Which of the following is true regarding the suspected paranasal sinus involvement?
A. Swelling over the cheeks
B. Upper eyelid involved
C. Swelling over the medial canthus of the eye
D. Pain increases on stooping
E. The most commonly affected sinus in sinusitis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This is a case of maxillary sinusitis. Mucoid or mucopurulent discharge in the middle meatus is pathognomonic of maxillary sinusitis.

Maxillary sinusitis:

  • Redness and swelling over the cheek (Statement A)
  • Headache in the forehead region.
  • Pain aggravated on coughing, stooping or chewing(Statement D)
  • Most commonly involved sinusitis in adults. (In children, ethmoid sinusitis is most common)(Statement e)
  • There can be lower eyelid involvement. (Upper eyelid is involved in frontal sinusitis. Both eyelids are involved in ethmoid sinusitis).(Statement B)
  • In Ethmoid sinusitis, pain is over the medial canthus, over the bridge of the nose. It is aggravated by movements of the eyeball.(Statement c)

questions.text: All the following are complications of sphenoid sinus surgery except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Orbital emphysema is more common when the lamina papyracea is damaged. Lamina papyracea, part of the ethmoid bone, separates the orbit from ethmoidal air cells, making orbital emphysema a complication of ethmoid sinus surgery


Explanation of other options:

  • Optic nerve injury(Option B):The optic nerve often runs in close proximity to the lateral wall of the sphenoid sinus. During surgery, especially if the bone covering the nerve is dehiscent or very thin, there's a real risk of trauma which can result in potential blindness.
  • Abducens palsy(Option C):The abducens nerve (VI) courses through the cavernous sinus, adjacent to the sphenoid sinus. Surgical breach of the sinus roof or lateral walls can damage this nerve causing lateral rectus palsy (diplopia).
  • Internal carotid artery injury(Option D):It often lies in a bony canal just lateral to the sphenoid sinus. Unintentional entry or instrument penetration through the sinus wall can result in catastrophic ICA injury (hemorrhage, stroke, death).

questions.text: The frontal sinus can be best visualised by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Caldwell view (Occipitofrontal view or nose-forehead position):

  • Frontal sinus (seen best)
  • Shows all sinuses except the sphenoid sinus.

Water's view (occipitomental view or nose-chin position): (Option B)

  • Maxillary sinuses (seen best).
  • Shows all sinuses except the ethmoid
  • The sphenoid sinus is seen only if the film is taken with the mouth open.

Explanation of other options:

Towne's view (Option C) is taken for acoustic neuroma and apical petrositis.

Schuller's view (Option D) is taken for mastoiditis, cholesteatoma, and longitudinal fracture of the petrous pyramid.

questions.text: A patient presents with a cyst-like swelling in the superior medial side of the eye. There is no pain when it is pressed. This entity affects which paranasal sinus most commonly?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given description is suggestive of a mucocele.

Mucocele of paranasal sinuses:

  • Expansion of the bony wall of the sinus.
  • Frontal sinus is most commonly affected, followed by ethmoidal, maxillary & sphenoidal.
  • The treatment of choice is FESS.

Frontal mucocele:

  • Usually presents in the superomedial quadrant of the orbit, displacing the eyeball forward, downward and laterally.
  • Swelling is cystic, non-tender, and eggshell crackling may be present

questions.text: Most common site of osteomas among the paranasal sinuses:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Osteomas are benign, slow-growing bony tumors commonly found in the paranasal sinuses. They are usually asymptomatic and discovered incidentally, but can occasionally cause symptoms like sinus obstruction or headache if large.
  • The frontal sinus is the most common location for osteomas, accounting for up to 80% of all paranasal sinus osteomas.
  • They are often managed conservatively and surgical removal by endoscopy is the definitive treatment.

questions.text: Which facial sinus continues to grow even in adulthood?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Sphenoid sinus:

  • It reaches the sella turcica by around 7 years of age.
  • Dorsum sellae by the late teens.
  • And finally extends to the basisphenoid region in adulthood.
  • It reaches full size only between 15 years to adult age, unlike other sinuses, which complete development earlier.

questions.text: A 23-year-old person suffering from acute frontal sinusitis has developed a painful red forehead swelling (see the image). Which of the following is the best description of the condition?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

This clinical scenario is suggestive of Pott's puffy tumour.

  • It is osteomyelitis of the frontal bone, and pus collects externally under the periosteum (subperiosteal) as a soft, doughy swelling.
  • This happens as a complication of frontal sinusitis. This is more common in adults as the frontal sinus is not developed in infants and children.
  • Treatment:
    • Large doses of antibiotics, drainage of abscess and trephining of the frontal sinus through its floor.
    • Sometimes, removal of sequestra and necrotic bone by raising a scalp flap is required.

Explanation of other options:

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (Option A): It is a rare, life-threatening, septic venous thrombosis typically following facial or paranasal sinus infections characterized by fever, retro-orbital pain, ophthalmoplegia (especially sixth nerve), chemosis, and proptosis and confirmed on MRI/CT.

Frontoethmoidal Mucocele and Ringertz tumor (Option C&D) of frontal sinus are painless.

questions.text: A patient presents to her GP with recurrent nosebleeds and also complains of facial fullness and facial pain. Over the past 2 months, she has developed progressive shortness of breath, and on one occasion, she coughed up some blood. What would be the most appropriate test to perform?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • In the given clinical scenario, the most likely diagnosis is Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly known as Wegener's granulomatosis) and c-ANCA (cytoplasmic pattern), directed against proteinase 3 (PR3), is positive in over 90% of active cases GPA is a systemic necrotising vasculitis affecting:
    • Upper respiratory tract: nasal crusting, epistaxis, sinusitis, facial pain
    • Lower respiratory tract: cough, dyspnea, hemoptysis
  • Sinusitis is the most common ENT manifestation of this autoimmune disorder.
  • Septal perforation (bony and cartilaginous), saddle nose deformity with epistaxis, is commonly seen.
  • The multi-system involvement leads to pulmonary symptoms.
  • The biopsy from the nose reveals necrotising vasculitis in this case.

Explanation of other options:

  • ACE levels(Option A): ACE is elevated in sarcoidosis, not vasculitis. This patient's respiratory and ENT signs more closely fit Wegener's, not sarcoid.
  • Anti-GBM antibodies(Option B): These are seen in Goodpasture syndrome (pulmonary hemorrhage + rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis). The patient lacks renal signs like hematuria or kidney failure.

Factor VIII levels(Option D): These relate to coagulation disorders (e.g., hemophilia A) and do not explain ENT bleeding and systemic symptoms.
